Context:
The Culinary Management – Nutrition program is offered at George Brown College. It provides training in food and nutrition-focused environments such as restaurants, resorts, schools, spas, seniors' residences and long-term care facilities. Students learn through demonstrations, lectures, and hands-on culinary practice, and complete a seven-week industry work-integrated learning experience in their final semester. The program operates from Monday to Friday with classes that may begin as early as 7 a.m. and run until 10 p.m.

Graduates of this program can expect careers in various organizations related to food and nutrition, including restaurants, hotels, spas, resorts, schools, manufacturers, health and fitness facilities, seniors' residences and long-term care facilities, as well as the opportunity to start their own business as an entrepreneur.

George Brown College also offers a postgraduate Food and Nutrition Management Program (H402) for students who wish to take their careers to the next level in health care and nutrition. This one-year graduate certificate program is accredited.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Culinary Management – Nutrition Program H119 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The H402 Food and Nutrition Management program is accredited by the Canadian Society of Nutrition Management. The following are the required courses for the program spread over four semesters:

Semester 1:
- HOSF1029: Theory of Food 1
- HOST1068: Smart Serve
- HOSF1294: Nutrition And Wellness
- HOSF1229: Nutrition Analysis and Food Labelling
- HOSF1247: Culinary Nutrition Skills – Foundations
- HOSF1248: Culinary Nutrition Skills – Essentials
- HOSF1145: Sanitation
- HOSF1146: Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR (weekend course)
- MATH1200: Culinary Math Essentials
- COMM2000: Communicating Across Contexts
- GSCI1035: Science of Sustainability

Semester 2:
- HOSF1257: Nutrition and Culture
- HOSF1191: Culinary Nutrition - Desserts
- HOSF1249: Culinary Nutrition Skills – Cultures I
- HOSF1250: Culinary Nutrition Skills – Cultures II
- HOSF1226: Introduction to the Science of Food
- HOST1005: Food, Beverage and Labour Cost Control (Hybrid)
- HOSF2040: Advanced Sanitation
- HOST 1126: Career Preparation
- HOSF 1287: WHMIS
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 3:
- HOSF1156: Nutrition for Life
- HOSF2036: Menu Applications
- HOSF2037: Introduction to Quality Assurance
- HOSF2069: Culinary Nutrition for Life I
- HOSF2056: Introduction to Industry Research Project
- HOSF2081: Hospitality Leadership and Communication
- HOSF2070: Culinary Nutrition for Life II

Semester 4:
- HOSF1159: Chef’s Kitchen
- HOSF2041: Fundamentals of Wine and Service
- HOSF2042: Quantity Cooking for Nutrition Issues
- HOSF2043: Nutrition Issues
- HOSF2057: Capstone Project

* denotes courses with an asterisk are likely to be practical or lab-based.

Context:
The text provides information about a college program titled "Hospitality and Service Management - Culinary Arts" (implied from context). The following are key factual information extracted from the text:

- Students may be required to take COMM 1000 as a prerequisite before certain communication courses.
- General Education Electives are part of the program and include a seven-week course.
- Course offerings under this program include HOSF2043 - Nutrition Issues, HOSF2057 - Culinary Industry Research and Development (Interactive Lab), HOSF2075 - Industry Externship.
- Students are expected to learn various skills such as advanced culinary planning, preparation, presentation for different food service environments, applying food science, maintaining kitchen environment, ensuring safe kitchen operations, creating menus reflecting nutrition knowledge, managing food service operations, using technology for food production, and performing effectively as a team member.
- Students are expected to learn business principles, costing practices, sustainability, ethics, local food sourcing, and food security.
- The text mentions visiting "Assessment Centre" for more information about COMM 1000 requirement.

No specific names, emails or years were mentioned in the text.

Context:
* Tuition and Fees:
  - Domestic Tuition: $7,819 for Fall 2023, subject to change for Fall 2024 and later
  - International Tuition: $21,195 for Fall 2024, subject to change
  - Additional costs (estimated total for first two semesters): $7,819 for Domestic students, $21,195 for International students (for Fall 2023), $NA for later years
  - Additional costs include small wares ($100–$300) and textbooks ($700)
  - Semester 1 tuition fees include the cost of a culinary kit, safety shoes, and Chef School uniform
* Financial Assistance: Program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria
* Admission Requirements: Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, Grade 12 English (C or U), or mature student status (19 years of age or older) and take the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade English credits. Meeting minimum requirements does not guarantee admission to the program.
* Disclaimer: Information is subject to change without notice. Students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements.

Context:
* Applicants may need grades higher than minimum requirements for admission to some programs.
* Course exemptions may be granted based on college or university credits. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide page.
* International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Students with allergens such as nuts, dairy, and shellfish should be aware that they are used in practical labs. George Brown College is sensitive to religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
* For inquiries about domestic admission requirements, deadlines, or the admissions process, contact the Admissions Office at [admissions@georgebrown.ca](mailto:admissions@georgebrown.ca) or visit the Admissions web page.
* For financial aid and fees-related inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at [FinAid@georgebrown.ca](mailto:FinAid@georgebrown.ca) or visit the Financial Aid web page.
* Inquiries about the Culinary Management-Nutrition (H119) program should be directed to [CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca](mailto:CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca).
* Contact George Brown College by calling 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002, or contact one of their international recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin through a virtual meeting or inquiry on the International Contact Us page.
* Visit George Brown College's campus for Discovery Days to learn more about areas of interest and meet with representatives. Sign up for an Open House Discovery Day and explore related programs like Culinary Management (H100) and Food and Nutrition Management (Postgraduate).
